head_text.subj: EXT. KATTEGAT SEA, JUTLAND, DENMARK, 1920'S, DAY

text: A rectangle of ferociously stormy sea viewed from battere cliffs. Silver waves are whipped by a wind that flies at stinging, relentless. Somewhere, unseen in the barren landscape, something is at its mercy - we hear the RUSTLE PUNCH of the weather going at it...

The same scene reflected across the surface of a woman’s brown eye, intense with emotion, curiosity. Gradually, th WEATHER SOUNDS are overtaken by VOICES coming up. At firs the SOCIAL CHATTER is PERIPHERAL, then the VOICES grow mo STRIDENT, OPPRESSIVE. The eye blinks.
A painting of the same sea, captured with remarkable accu of feeling. A HUBBUB OF GABBLING VOICES. Too many people a low-ceilinged room. One voice dominates now -
Don't you wish you could paint like that? We pull out to see GERDA WEGENER’S brown eyes shift from scrutiny of the painting to polite social focus as she ta in an excited OLDER WOMAN.
I’m sorry...?

I said, don't you wish you could paint like your husband? Really - you must be so proud... The woman smiles and heads into the crowd, leaving Gerda consider... Gerda’s gaze travels across the well-dressed gathering. Far off in a corner, there’s an inner circle where her handsome husband EINAR WEGENER is being showere with praise. A portly goateed man dominates the scene - RASMUSSEN, Einar’s dealer.
They're all Veijle, where he grew up. (CONTINUED)

Gerda begins walking toward them through the throng... RASMUSSEN (cont'd) And I don't say my client is the best landscape artist in Denmark... but, he is in the top one! Einar cringes as the crowd laughs, delighted. An exotic- looking woman with mischief playing on her full lips approaches Gerda. This is ULLA FONSMARCK. They're friends
(a stage whisper) It's going very well.

Oh yes. He’1l be impossible. The women LAUGH. As Gerda looks up, Einar looks across, smiles, trapped in his corner. Gerda nods back, reassurin conspiratorial. Then Einar’s pulled back into the select circle and Rasmussen emits a ridiculous barking LAUGH.

Gerda and Einar, arm in arm, LAUGHING. Gerda wears a distinctively embroidered fine wool wrap. Their FOOTSTEPS ring down the empty street. A patina of crystallised brin coats doorways, windows, scintillating in the moonlight.
And Rasmussen...
Oh, come on. Be kind. At least he agreed to see your work.
Only because he was drunk!
I know.
You were loving it!
I was not. She mimics Rasmussen, his ludicrous excitement:
“I don’t say my client is the best landscape artist in Denmark...” (CONTINUED)
“He is in the top one!” They LAUGH hard. Someone calls from an upstairs window:
Hey - people are sleeping! The window SLAMS. Gerda and Einar struggle to quieten dow head for the dancing harbour lights - partners in crime.
Fishermen selling straight off the boats to early-rising customers. Prices are loudly negotiated as the silver cat still writhes and flaps. A city coming to life.

head_text.subj: INT. THE WIDOW HOUSE, BEDROOM, MORNING

text: Gerda carries in a breakfast tray. Einar sleeps. She obse his face: long eyelashes, cheeks hollow in repose, delica lips. A little dog, HVAPPE, trots beside her. She puts do the tray and throws back the bedcover. Einar blinks in th light, surprised. He stretches, takes in the silhouetted outline of his wife: tall, purposeful Gerda.
Do you know what time it is? He smiles, sweetly suggestive of pleasure to come...
Time you came back to bed?
No - I’m ready to start work.
Draw down the blinds. She holds back, teases a little.
I told you, I...
Gerda...
What? (CONTINUED)
She takes him in, smiling up at her. Shakes her head. GERDA (cont'd) Your face... You think I can’t resist you...
Do you want to resist me? She approaches the edge of the bed, smiling herself now.
No. But I’d like you to ask nicely so I don’t feel such a pushover... Einar reaches towards her.
Gerda Wegener - my life, my wife... He pulls her into bed... A skittish piano comes up as the laugh, begin to make love. Continues over:
Einar crosses the road, heads for the Opera House.
Einar greets the doorman, THORBJORN.
Thorbjorn.
Mr Wegener.

head_text.subj: INT. OPERA HOUSE, COSTUME SHOP, ONE MONTH LATER, DAY

text: Einar walks between racks of clothes that hang in two tie so the ruffled and feathered hems of jewel-coloured gowns brush his cheeks. An explicit sensual pleasure, which Ein is conscious of but feels no need to investigate. He paus The ARIA ceases, he hears women CHATTING, sometimes DROPP THEIR VOICES, emitting DIRTY LAUGHS, which make him smile wonder. A stolen intimacy. Einar spies on Ulla, below -
Tighter! Ulla is being pulled into a corset by a DRESSER. Einar le forward for a better view... She spots him - is delighted breaks free for a moment. (CONTINUED)
ULLA (cont'd) Einar Wegener! The DRESSER hands Ulla a robe to cover up, but: ULLA (cont'd) Oh don’t worry about him - he’s only ever had eyes for one woman.
My guilty secret’s out. He smiles at her, indulgent. She calls up to him -
So - when are you two going to breed me a godchild?
You’re an atheist.
I’1l reconsider.
We're trying.
Try harder. I’ve been waiting an eternity. Have you tried drinking raw eggs?
No.
Do it. For my sake. Einar shakes his head. She’s impossible and he adores her ULLA (cont'd) Anyway what are you doing in today? I thought you finished last week?
I wanted to check on the scrim for the storm scene. And give Gerda some space.
Ah - she’s got a shy one. Einar nods, smiles. Ulla prepares to resume her fitting. ULLA (cont'd) You know I’m next?
So I heard. (CONTINUED)
I won’t be shy.
I should imagine not.
Good God, she’ll need all her colours for me! They LAUGH and Ulla signals to the dresser to pull at the corset once more, smiles in delighted anticipation of the discomfort to come.

MR FONNESBECH in a chair on a slightly raised dais. He is formally dressed, somewhat stiff. The room is oppressivel still. Gerda looks up from her canvas, goes to adjust Fonnesbech’s arm. He is clearly affected by being touched embarrassed. She returns to the canvas. After an uncomfortable couple of moments:
I wanted to say... I appreciate our being alone today. I hope your husband doesn’t mind.
Not at all. I could see his being here made you uncomfortable.
It wasn’t personal. Gerda smiles. Shakes her head - he shouldn’t worry:
It’s not uncommon.
Ah. Fonnesbech’s relieved. Though he’s left with questions.

It’s hard for a man to be looked at by a woman. Women are used to it, of course, but for a man... Mr Fonnesbech begins to look wildly vulnerable. GERDA (cont'd) To... submit to a woman’s gaze. It’s unsettling... Fonnesbech nods, relieved - that’s exactly it. (CONTINUED)

GERDA (cont'd) Although I believe there’s some pleasure to be had from it, once you... She smiles mischievously. GERDA (cont'd) «yield. Fonnesbech swallows, cheeks pinking. Suddenly: GERDA (cont'd) sit! Fonnesbech flinches. The dog settles. Fonnesbech exhales. GERDA (cont'd) Good girl. Gerda returns to work, eyes glinting at what she’s reveal in her sitter: finally getting somewhere.
A CHINESE LAUNDRESS with a large wheeled cart makes her w along the street, RINGING a pair of little BELLS as she g
Einar quickly but carefully folds Gerda’s chemise and put in a bag of laundry, hurries to open the door...

head_text.subj: INT/EXT. WIDOW HOUSE, EARLY MORNING, A MONTH LATER

text: Einar hands the bag to the laundress as she passes.
Gerda at the mirror, putting on her lipstick. Einar comes in, reacts, seeing her dressed up. She’s self-conscious.
Well? Einar can’t help smiling at her implied self-criticism.
Perfect. Almost. He approaches, uses his thumb to gently blend away a smud of lipstick from her bottom lip. He nods. Perfect now. EINAR (cont'd) Good luck... 26/11/15
Gerda carries her heavy portfolio, optimistic, brisk.
Rasmussen's face - a look of slight distaste. A sea of Gerda’s work, on the desk, the floor - competent but uninspiring naturalistic depictions of society figures.
All portraits... Gerda hesitates a beat, the fact being so self-evident.
Is that bad?

Not per se, but... this kind of work is not really my... He winces a little. He has to end this: RASMUSSEN (cont'd) Gerda... I don’t think it would benefit either of us to show these. A vein begins to throb in Gerda’s neck. RASMUSSEN (cont'd) It’s not a judgement on your abilities - I agree with Einar: you could be a first class painter if you found the right subject matter. It’s the first time Gerda’s heard this. Her eyes shine, stung, betrayed.
Einar works, hears the door. Gerda brings in the portfoli sets it down, starts taking off her coat. Einar’s tentati
How was it?
Fine. He waits for more, but nothing comes.
I finally mixed the right colour for the snow. (CONTINUED)
Gerda glances at the canvas, hostile.
Another view of Vejle. I don’t know how you can paint the same thing over and over. Einar misses a beat.
I suppose I just haven’t finished with it yet. Gerda heads towards the door. EINAR (cont'd) Gerda..?

Could you please not speak to Rasmussen about me again... My work is my business. Stay out of it. But she disappears into the bedroom, the door slamming emphatically behind her. Einar’s left bewildered.
Gerda’s already regretting the exchange with Einar. She unfastens her dress, pulls it off. There’s a bloodstain i her underwear. Damn! She breathes.
Einar working as Gerda reappears. She’s composed now, refocused, approaches her easel, organises her paints. Ei steals a look at her, but says nothing. Works on. Eventually:
I have my period.
I’m sorry.
Are you? She turns to find him approaching.
Of course I am... You know I am. A moment of quiet intimacy between them. Gerda shies away returns to present concerns... her work... (CONTINUED)
Could you help me with something? Einar’s relieved to be able to help.
Anything.

Ulla has an extra rehearsal. She cancelled again. Would you try on her stockings and shoes? Einar’s discomfort erupts in a laugh. Is she serious? GERDA (cont'd) I'm just so behind. I don’t know how I’11 be finished in time for her opening... But he cuts her off:

I'll do it. It’s fine. Gerda sets a shoebox and the stocking on the sitter’s cha goes into the kitchen. Einar moves the box and stockings, sits in the chair on the dais. The dog leaps up - EINAR (cont'd) No... no, not now Hvappe... He pushes Hvappe down, tests the mesh of the stockings be fingers. He rolls up his trousers. EINAR (cont'd) He almost snagged this... Gerda marvels at his delicacy. Scolds the dog:

Hvappe... Gerda mixes paints. Einar battles with the stockings. GERDA (cont'd) That’s backwards... He fiddles with the second stocking now, a light sweat de his forehead by the time he’s rolled both to the knee. He opens a shoebox: - the yellow pair from the shop window.
I saw these in the window of Fonnesbech’s...
Smart aren’t they? (CONTINUED)
I don’t think they'll fit...

Well just do what you can. He takes them out... Something catches in Einar’s throat he pushes his toes into the shoe. Gerda’s eyes are narrow she starts work. Einar looks down at his feet, partly contained in the yellow suede, the disjuncture between th body above and below the knee... he breathes... can’t kee his hands steady. Then: GERDA (cont'd) No. I need the dress. They both look over to where Ulla’s dress hangs. It is wh weighted with beads at the hem and cuff. Beautiful.
Gerda, I’m not putting it on.

I haven’t asked you to. She get sit... lays it across him. GERDA (cont'd) Would you just relax...? The sooner I start, the sooner I finish. Einar yields reluctantly, as Gerda runs her fingers gentl down his face. Satisfied, Gerda returns to work. Einar’s breathing feels slightly laboured now. The dress weighs heavily. His head moves slightly, feeling it brush his neck. His fingers curl involuntarily around the beade cuff. The SOUNDSCAPE becomes heightened: the creak of Gerda’s easel, the jangling of her bracelets, the sound o the harbour, the wind in the ships’ riggings. These combi fill his head... until:

Well hello, there! Einar starts... Ulla’s in the doorway, delighted, with a bunch of lilies. She starts to LAUGH, and because it’s Ul Gerda LAUGHS also. The dog YAPS, excited, confused. Einar disoriented. Gerda sees this, stops laughing, but... ULLA (cont'd) Oh, don’t worry my darling... She hands the flowers to him, kisses him: ULLA (cont'd) We're going to call you Lili... (CONTINUED)
Einar manages to laugh now as the dog runs BARKING in circles, Ulla’s delight banishing the day’s frustrations.
There are lights on in the Widow House.

Gerda closes the book she’s been reading, looks up to see Einar, working, engrossed. An almost trance-like state. S watches him a while, then approaches, rests her head agai his back. He’s comfortable with this, but works on.

Such concentration. Sometimes when you're working, I think you’re going to slip through the surface of the painting and vanish. He smiles a little. GERDA (cont'd) Sink into the bog. Like your friend’s kite when you were a boy.
Hans. It was Hans’ kite I crashed. Einar enjoys the memory for a moment. EINAR (cont'd) Poor Hans. He was so proud of it... I couldn’t believe he even let me have a turn...
He’s probably still sitting on a rock, sobbing his heart out. Einar sets down his brush, turns toward her, away from hi work, smiles.
He’s a dealer in Paris, peddling Old Masters to rich Americans.
Oh. So we don’t need to worry about Hans.
No we don’t. He takes her in. (CONTINUED)
I didn’t mean to disturb you.

That's okay. I’ve finished. He kisses her. EINAR (cont'd) And don’t worry, I won’t disappear into the bog. He widens his eyes, surprised at his own realisation: EINAR (cont'd) The bog is in me, silly. She pushes him off, LAUGHING.

head_text.subj: INT. WIDOW HOUSE, BEDROOM, LATER THAT NIGHT

text: Einar’s in bed. Gerda pulls off her dress, looks round to see him watching her as she lays her stockings over the c beside her dressing table.
What?
Can’t a man watch his wife get undressed? She goes to take off her lace-edged slip, self-conscious EINAR (cont'd) That slip is new...
You're very observant.
Leave it on... She hesitates, but Einar pulls back the sheet... Gerda ke the slip on, climbs in beside him. He strokes her body through the silk... EINAR (cont'd) It’s very pretty...
I might let you borrow it. Einar shrugs, rising flirtatiously to the challenge.
I might enjoy that. (CONTINUED)
Gerda LAUGHS, and Einar kisses her. She teases:
Oh really...? Is there something you’d like to tell me?
Why...? Is there something you'd like to know...? His fingers trace, quivering, over her...
No... I’m your wife. I know everything. Einar thrills, pulls her on top of him, a fresh passion, fresh risk about their union.

head_text.subj: INT. COSTUME SHOP, LATER THAT NIGHT

text: A champagne cork POPS. Ulla’s triumphant first night. She on magnificent form, working the room. Gerda’s portrait h in pride of place. Gerda and Einar chat with a group that includes their friends NIELS and ELSA. Ulla swoops in, WHISPERS something in Gerda’s ear. Gerda’s eyes register delight as she looks across at two young men on the other side of the room.
Both of them...?
And at the same time! Einar laughs. Gerda shakes her head. ULLA (cont'd) Married people are so delightfully easy to shock.
We just pretend to be shocked because it encourages you.
I know. That’s why you’re the only couple in my party for the Artists Ball...
Out of the question.
Oh, I know Einar hates it, but he’1l have to bear with us. (CONTINUED)
She can go without me.
Gerda without an escort? It would be a scandal.
Gerda loves a scandal.
You've had too much champagne. Niels and Elsa hear this, tune in...
Look at the way she dresses, flaunting her ankles. An invitation to corruption.
I don’t think anyone is likely to be corrupted by seeing my ankles.

I was. The group laughs delighted by Einar’s buoyant mood. EINAR (CONT'D) (cont’d) The first time we met, I was leaving the Academy, and she was on the steps, flaunting said ankles... And she propositioned me!
Is that true?!
It was a dare. But when I said hello to him, he actually blushed! He was so shy! So I asked him out.
And you said yes - Einar scrutinises Gerda.
She made me. She seemed so sure.
I was sure. I still am.
Oh please - enough! Elsa elbows him, turns to Gerda. (CONTINUED)
No - what was it about him? Gerda looks at Einar.

I don’t know... She remembers, drawing Einar into the recollection. GERDA (cont'd) But we went for coffee, and after, I kissed him... and it was the strangest thing... it was like kissing myself. A look between Einar and Gerda, a connection crackling.
Well these two won’t be staying much longer...
Unmarried people are so delightfully easy to shock. She and Einar smile, make their way towards the door.
Einar comes in, Gerda’s already in bed. He starts to undress, turns out the light.

Turn it back on. He looks at her. She shrugs, smiles - it’s her turn, afte all... He turns it back on, a little awkward now, undress in front of her. She sees this, toughs it out, watching h anyway. GERDA (cont'd) Were you really corrupted by my ankles? Einar wears just his shirt now, begins to unbutton.
You were shameless.

I still am. Einar peels off his shirt. Underneath, he wears Gerda’s l edged slip. Gerda GASPS slightly... Einar has outdone her with this imaginative twist. But she rises to the occasio Feels the fabric against his body. (CONTINUED)
Beautiful shameless Gerda... She traces her fingers across his chest, challenged, arou

Einar asleep, a SCRATCHING sound in the background. We se quick charcoal strokes on paper, Gerda wrapped in Einar’s dressing gown, at the side of the bed. She’s fascinated, suddenly able to see the femininity of his features, play with it, creating a revised Einar... His eyes open...
Did I wake you? He raises his eyebrows, entertained. What does she think? She smiles, carries on working. GERDA (cont'd) Sorry... I couldn’t sleep.
Why?
Wondering about things.
What things?
Wondering if we made a baby last night. Einar smiles, surprised.
What d’you think? Gerda shrugs, keeps sketching.
Wondering when you got so pretty.
Oh, I was always pretty, you just never noticed. Gerda LAUGHS, keeps working.

head_text.subj: INT. WIDOW HOUSE, STUDIO, A WEEK LATER

text: In the studio, Einar looks at the sketches Gerda has made him, darkly fascinated. He hears Gerda come in. (CONTINUED)
Hello...?
In here... takes off her coat. Gerda comes in, puts down her workbag, Gerda’s a little self- Einar’s still looking at the sketches. conscious... EINAR (cont'd) These are good.

Do you think? He nods, absolutely serious. Gerda absorbs this, gratifie GERDA (cont'd) Well thank you. Thank you. Gerda goes out to hang up her coat, calls - GERDA (cont'd) I had coffee with Ulla. about the Artists’ Ball. She asked Einar draws breath to protest, but: GERDA (cont'd) Don’t worry - I told her no.
You should go, you enjoy it.
With you I enjoy it. Einar feels guilty.
Look - it’s good to be seen things. I understand that. at those
And that’s why you hate them. Gerda shrugs - she gets it. He smiles.
I feel as though I’m performing myself.
Giving them your Einar Wegener. Exactly. Gerda looks at him a moment. (CONTINUED)
GERDA (cont'd) Why not give them something different, go as someone else? She tilts her head. A look between them... this is a departure... Einar hesitates a moment...
Did you have someone in particular in mind? A mischievous smile spreads across Gerda’s face... she st to laugh, Einar begins to understand... laughs along... EINAR (cont'd) No - that’s outrageous!
You'd be very convincing... You might even enjoy it... Einar marvels at her... she’s only half-joking.
Gerda sweeps a layer of foundation over Einar’s face. Whe she’s done, he opens his eyes. Gerda’s taken aback.
You'll have to shave closer. Einar takes in his blanked-out face in the shaving mirror Gerda goes to apply eyeliner... GERDA (cont'd) Close your eyes... This is hard on someone else...
Here... Einar takes the crayon, draws a couple of pretty good lin EINAR (cont'd) How’s that? She marvels at his reflection. It’s bizarrely compelling.
Better than I ever manage. His reflection looks back. Gerda’s energy is up... She drapes her scarf around his neck... GERDA (cont'd) Oh, Lili! I want to sketch you... (CONTINUED)
She hurries him through to the studio... arranges cushion the chaise. GERDA (cont'd) sit! Einar sits - a distinctive pose.
Come on, Hvap! Hvappe jumps onto his lap. Gerda sketches quickly, absorb excited. She rearranges him, ‘feminising’ his poses.

Knee over... head up.. Look at those hands... relax... We see Einar at a series of angles... but his movements a more and more parodically feminine for Gerda’s entertainm The more he acts it, the more fun it is, until finally Ge scolds, still laughing: GERDA (cont'd) No, don’t make her a slut!
It’s your fault, you excite her. Gerda gets close to pin him still. His face closes on her
Why, Miss Lili, you are forward...
You have no idea... He falls on her, laughing, passionate... Gerda responds, grabs a cloth and wipes his made-up face as he kisses her MONTAGE BEGINS -—
We see Gerda’s work around the room, now, depicting ‘Lili progress. Einar, at the mirror, plucks his eyebrows to be resemble the glamorous arch in Gerda’s sketches.
Einar and Gerda walk, a little way apart. He feels his wa into her gait, she checks back on his progress. 26/11/15  43 21.
As Gerda buys fish, Einar is distracted, observing and copying the movements of the female customer beside him..
Gerda and Einar arrive. The stage doorman nods.
Morning, Thorbjorn... 43
Good morning.

head_text.subj: INT. OPERA HOUSE, COSTUME SHOP, DAY

text: Gerda and Einar try on wigs, surreptitious, excited, adju one another’s choices. Then, a long line of almost identi shoes, beginning in tiny sizes but gradually getting bigg Einar grabs the last - biggest - pair. When he looks up, Gerda’s showing him a dress...

head_text.subj: INT. OPERA HOUSE, STAGE DOOR, DAY

text: Einar and Gerda head out past the stage doorman, very ple with themselves. Gerda is several sizes fatter and taller she wears a wig with a hat on top. Hands stuffed into coa pockets hide bulky shoes. Thorbjorn looks up briefly from his newspaper. Then as the door closes behind Einar and Gerda, he looks up again - ? - MONTAGE ENDS -—

The Lili sketches depict a gamut of moods, face and postu already becoming iconic. Einar in the slip and the new shoes, practising his walk to settle his nerves. Hears th front door open - quickly calls:
I wondered where you were, it’s getting late. Gerda comes in...
We have plenty of time. I bought these... Einar takes the stockings with interest. Gerda watches, entertained at his enthusiasm, but a little apprehensive. (CONTINUED)
GERDA (cont'd) Einar, are you sure about tonight? Einar looks up, surprised. Nods, without hesitation. Gerda’s a little taken aback at his enthusiasm.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET NEAR CANAL, NEAR ROYAL ACADEMY OF ARTS, NIGHT

text: Dancing light and sound - up ahead, we see a glamorous, eclectic gathering: the fun-loving, the arrogant, the eccentric, the bourgeois - all rubbing shoulders on their way to the Royal Academy. Two pairs of women’s feet in step: Gerda and Einar, appro the melee. Then Gerda realises Einar has slowed, dropped back behind her. She turns to see him transformed in a chiffon dress with a linen sailor’s collar and cuffs...
What is it...? Einar’s eyes shine animated. He cuts an ungainly figure, the impression is more confusing than jarring.
Am I pretty enough? Gerda’s surprised by the sincerity of the question.
Of course you are... He takes Gerda’s hand and she pulls closer.

I’ll never be as pretty as you. Gerda studies the features, the fire behind the eyes. An intensity she had not been expecting... something new... charged moment... Gerda’s genuinely moved... but then Einar/Lili laughs, breaks away... leaving Gerda with a be of emotion that doesn’t belong anywhere.

head_text.subj: INT. ROYAL ACADEMY OF ARTS, STAIRCASE, NIGHT

text: Gerda and ‘Lili’ mingle with the crowd. A VOICE rings out
My darling! A flicker of fear in Lili... until Gerda interposes herse
Ulla, let me introduce... (CONTINUED)
Ulla’'s eyes snag for a moment as they search the familia face and realisation dawns. Delight floods her face. Then
It’s Lili...!
That's right. Einar’s cousin from Vejle...

My dear, you're exquisite... She LAUGHS, thrilled, exchanges a look with Gerda. Lili’s eyelashes flutter, a picture of shyness as Ulla summons t rest of her party - revelling in their shared secret... ULLA (CONT'D) (cont'd) In - let’s go in... Gerda and Lili - holding hands - join the crush:
You won’t leave me, will you...? Gerda looks down at Einar/Lili’s grip on her hand.
(sincerely) No. No, never. She squeezes the hand and they press forward together.

head_text.subj: INT. ROYAL ACADEMY OF ARTS, GREAT HALL, NIGHT

text: A spectacular event. An orchestra plays and people dance. Ulla’s party drink and laugh. Gerda and Lili hang back a little, observing. There’s a circle of men in tuxedos nea One glances across at Lili. Lili looks away, blushing.
People are looking.
Well you're a pretty girl, you'll have to get used to that. But she sees Lili’s really uncomfortable. GERDA (CONT'D) (cont’d) It’s fine. You're just feeling self-conscious.
Gerda - ! They spot Elsa across the crowd... Lili shrinks. (CONTINUED)
Go and talk to her...
No, I‘’1l stay with you...

Go. I’ll be fine. Go before she comes over here... Gerda reluctantly crosses the room and greets Elsa warmly But by the time she glances back, Lili has gone. Lili sits at the edge of the dancefloor on a bench carved with mermaids, a nerve fluttering in her cheek. We see a young man, HENRIK SANDAHL, study her closely - closely en to see she is not everything she appears, but this only s to intrigue him. He sits beside her. Lili self-consciousl takes a notebook from her bag, begins to jot things down. Henrik leans in, his raven hair in Lili’s peripheral visi leans forward until Lili’s refusal to engage becomes comi
Are you a reporter? Lili looks up.
(flatly) No.

A poetess...? Lili packs up the notebook and hurries away... Finds a corridor, leading off the hall - quieter, darker... Lili feels her way along the wall, relieved to be in the cooler air, away from the party. As her eyes adjust to th darkness, she sees a couple kissing in an alcove. A flash the woman’s white thigh, as the man pushes up her dress. Lili turns away, discomfited, walks straight back into Henrik. HENRIK (CONT'D) (cont'd) Do you know the story of this oak tree?
Mm...? Henrik indicates a tree outside, behind Lili...
They say if you eat its acorns you can make a wish and become anyone you want for a day. (CONTINUED)
Einar’s reaction flashes through Lili’s facade.
Why would they say that...? Henrik bows, entertained by the effect he’s had...
Henrik Sandahl. At your disposal. A moment’s hesitation, then:
Lili...
Are you here with someone, Lili?
Yes - my cousin’s wife.
Who’s your cousin? Lili hesitates, turns back:
Einar Wegener. He’s a painter.
Rather a good one. Better than most people think.
Is that right?
Most people our age at any rate.
Well.... She makes to leave again, but:
Don’t go back in. It’s cooler here. Besides, I’m a romantic.
Oh really...
I prefer the shadows and... Lili steals a look at him. He lowers his voice... sincere (CONTINUED )

A digestif, Hans? It’s so chilly all of a sudden. I feel the cold these days. I don’t know why...
Thank you. Hans sits, but his eyes wander to the portraits that are ranged around the room. A kaleidoscope of Lili.
I’m so sorry Einar couldn’t be here. He told me: in Vejle you were his great friend. Both always plotting to getting away!
That’s true... (CONTINUED)
Such a tedious place! He said you’d sit and look out together, beyond the fjord.. to the sea... to the future.
Oh, we had big dreams...
And you were the only one who let him paint in peace, who told him it was alright to be a painter. Gerda returns to the room. Hans searches Lili’s face for remains of his old friend Einar.
He... used to sketch my portrait. Take a stone and draw me on the rocks at the side of the road. Gerda turns to Hans:
I didn’t know that.
Oh yes.
Would you like to see more of Einar’s work...?
Do we have any? Gerda’s surprised, unsettled by the question.
Yes, of course, Lili...
Oh, but couldn’t we see it another time? I so want to hear more from Hans... Hans, are you married?
No...
Why not? Gerda flinches, but: LILI (cont'd) He doesn’t mind, do you...? Gerda looks helpless. Hans takes over: (CONTINUED)
I've... been on my own a long time now. I’m too set in my ways.
I think marriage is the single thing we should all hope for in life.
Really? Lili looks utterly buoyant...
It creates someone else, more than just the two of you. It would be terrible never to know that... Her expression crumbles... Hans looks to Gerda...
Lili... Lili’s dissolving...
Excuse me. She hurries out towards the bedroom, clearly in distress. Hans struggles to comprehend the situation...
You... you ought to go...
No - let me help... She turns, holds Hans’ hands... the intimacy, intensity o connection surprises him:
Please - please - I’m sorry... He resigns himself to leaving... as he reaches the door:
Goodnight Lili...
Goodnight... Hans lets himself out. In the bedroom, Gerda, still shocked, looks at Lili - bewildered, afraid, head hanging. LILI (cont'd) I don’t think he noticed anything, do you? (CONTINUED)
I don’t know...
No, I think I got out just in time.
Sleep now. We’1ll talk more tomorrow.
Can I borrow a nightdress? Gerda’s shocked.
No... we’ve never done that. Lili’s never spent the night... Einar confesses:
It doesn’t matter what I wear. When I dream, they’re Lili’s dreams... Gerda struggles to accommodate this, very reluctant... bu she gives in, nods. What else can she do?
Gerda in bed. Lili’s sleeping head on the pillow next to her, where Einar’s once was. Gerda turns out the light.
Gerda arrives to find Lili in a bright dress with matchin scarf. Shopping bags everywhere. Slight tension in the ai
A new dress...
And this. Do you like it? She hands Gerda a bright scarf...
Yes. It’s perfect for you... Gerda hands it back. GERDA (cont'd) We're actually a little short of money at the moment. Lili hangs the scark back round Gerda’s neck, hardly miss beat: (CONTINUED)
I know, but now I’m back, I can sit for you again, can’t I...? That worked well before, Gerda, didn’t it...? Lili and Gerda take each other in, on a new footing...

Gerda paints Lili who has found a new stillness. A more serious spirit beneath the translucent skin. A sense of h growing into herself. We see on the wall now a number of double portraits, tell the story of a developing negotiation - Gerda and Lili depicted together, with a sense of close friendship or a wistful attempt at coupledom. Now Gerda paints with Lili advising... The two collaborating, a sense of shared vision. And throughout, we see Lili fully imagined as a woman, an increasingly idealised one - unrealistically lovely...

head_text.subj: INT. ETIENNE DUFOUR GALLERY, RAINY NIGHT, ONE MONTH LATER

text: Another show of ‘Lili’ paintings. A lot of the paintings the two as a couple, but Gerda is here alone. She feels i She works the room, determined, then sees Hans, across th crowd. Misses a beat. They make their way toward one another. An awkward social kiss. Gerda’s unusually brittl
It’s a good crowd.
She's a popular girl. Thank you for coming.
Thank you for asking me. I thought you'd forgotten all about me.
We've been busy.
Is Einar here?
Einar hates this kind of thing.
That’s a shame. For you, I mean. (CONTINUED)
I don’t mind. Hans wonders about this... lets it go.
Is he well...?
He’s excited. We have an old friend coming to town: Ulla Fonsmarck, the dancer. Do you know her?
I don’t think so. Could I take you to dinner? To celebrate? Someone ought to.
No. Thank you. Hans absorbs this, regroups.
Gerda, have I offended you?
No.
Gerda... He rests his hand on her arm, pressing for some honesty.. Gerda’s cornered, the heat of the room, the nearness of H
I am still Einar’s wife. She brushes past him, into the crowd. A MAN’S VOICE calls

Hans! Hans’ social mask slips quickly back into place. Later: CLOSE ANGLE on Gerda, watching as a flirtatious wo WHISPERS something in Hans’ ear. His eyes widen, he LAUGH Gerda looks away. Quickly sets down her drink and moves through the crowd toward the door... A GALLERY EMPLOYEE frets as Gerda pulls on her coat.
At least take an umbrella...
I'm fine, honestly... (CONTINUED)
If you just wait a minute someone will drive you... But Gerda’s out in the rain, the party still in full swin
Gerda lets herself in, breathless. Lili’s just arranging supper table, is surprised to see Gerda home so early...
Gerda...? Oh - you’re wet through. Gerda seems angry. Lili tries to stay buoyant... LILI (cont'd) Did it go well...? Tell me - how was it?
You'd know if you’d been there. Lili falters, then points to the table... set with flower
I’ve made us a supper...
You should have come.
A little sort of celebration...
This is not how it goes! We do these things together!
That's you and Einar. Gerda’s pent-up frustration begins to boil over...
Stop playing that stupid, stupid game!
Don’t you say this is a game!
You should have been there!
How could I be? Look at me! This further enrages Gerda - (CONTINUED)
Not everything’s about you! Gerda is suddenly overwhelmed with emotion - GERDA (cont'd) I need to see Einar. Lili flinches, shakes her head, touches Gerda, tender.
Let me help... Gerda cuts her off sharply, desperation building:
I need my husband. Just get him!
I can't... Lili’s eyes cloud. Gerda moderates, already losing hope..

I want to talk to my husband. I want to hold my husband. I need him. Can you get him? Can you at least try? Lili’s pained by the request. Her eyes plead, but Gerda’s desperate, won’t give up. Finally Lili shakes her head, desperately sorry. Gerda turns on her heel. The front doo BANGS as she heads off into the night, leaving Lili alone deeply sad.
Gerda sits in the dark, watching the rain on the pond. EXT. HANS AXGIL’S APARTMENT, NIGHT Hans heads for his building, is amazed to see Gerda on th front step...

Gerda... what is it? She gets to her feet... HANS (cont'd) You're soaked... He goes to comfort her, and she embraces him... initiates desperate snatched kiss before breaking away, upset. Hans pursues her... (CONTINUED)
HANS (cont'd) Gerda... wait...
I can't...
Wait... He hurries to catch up.

Lili transitioning to Einar. It happens awkwardly, and wh Einar looks in the mirror, he’s baffled by his reflection I/E. HANS’ CAR/RAINY STREETS, NIGHT Hans drives an exhausted Gerda, pulls up outside their building.
Will you be alright?
I'm always alright. He reaches for her hand. Gerda stiffens.
For God’s sake. Take some kindness where you can. He keeps hold of her hand. Gerda feels the warmth of him. Her eyes fill.
Einar always comes back in the end. He always has...
Maybe this time... he just can’t.

I’m sorry. Gerda shakes her head, gently rejecting Hans. GERDA (cont'd) I’ve never not finished a painting, I don’t know how to give up. Hans smiles, rueful. Finally lets Gerda take back her han 26/11/15  60.
Gerda appears in the doorway. Sees Einar sitting in the chair by the bed. She’s struck by how vulnerable he looks He looks up, and with genuine regret:

I don’t think I can give you what you want... He looks away, ashamed. It’s unbearable. Gerda approaches him. He looks like Lili dressed as Einar. EINAR/LILI (cont'd) I don’t know how long we can go on like this.
No. She pushes in beside him. Einar/Lili lies in Gerda’s lap. They hold each other into the night.

head_text.subj: EXT. OPERA GARNIER, PARIS, TWO WEEKS LATER, NIGHT

text: Establishing shot.

head_text.subj: INT. OPERA GARNIER, STAGE, NEXT DAY

text: Einar watches a group of dancers rehearse on stage. Sitti in the stalls, Gerda and Ulla are talking, as Ulla unbind her feet. We see callouses over the knuckles of her toes, toenails broken and sore. She’s used to this.
He needs to see someone. Gerda checks Einar’s well out of earshot.
You know what happened with Hexler.
But he’s so thin, Gerda...? There’s something wrong with him. Gerda looks across at Einar.
Lili watches her figure... Ulla lowers her voice -
Look, there’s a doctor - he runs the Women’s Clinic in Dresden. (CONTINUED)

Gerda’s face changes as she hears what Ulla’s telling her ULLA (cont'd) He’s interested in men like Einar. Men who are... different. Who are... confused. Gerda’s surprised. ULLA (cont'd) He’s often in Paris. Before Gerda can reply, Ulla is writing a name on a card ULLA (cont'd) Just talk to him? It couldn’t hurt, could it? - “Prof. Kurt Warnekros”. She gives the card to Gerda. Ge looks up at Einar. Finds him looking back, plainly exhaus
Gerda has made coffee. Einar comes in, dressed and with s energy.
Oh good... you’re awake... how do you feel? Einar nods - pretty good. She pours him coffee. GERDA (cont'd) Come.
I can’t - I have somewhere to go... He pulls on a jacket.
Where? He recoils from the question. Gerda gives up - GERDA (cont'd) I’m sorry - I don’t know how to hold on to you any longer.
I know. But I love you and I’m going to find an answer. 26/11/15
Einar at a desk piled high with books. He reads, driven, fascinated. We see the books: The Normal and Abnormal Man Scientific Study of Sexual Immorality...
Einar makes his way through the park. He looks bizarre in daylight, like a woman dressed as a man. He passes a coup of rough-looking younger men. One HISSES under his breath

Lesbian... Einar looks round, amazed, almost amused at the mistake.. when the men recognise that Einar is - in fact - a man, t LAUGH, shocked. Einar keeps walking, conscious of the men shadowing him, making silly obscene noises and comments. Einar presses on, anger and anxiety building as the men pursue. Now the men pull level with him, jostle, one movi ahead and rubbing his crotch. YOUNGER MAN (cont'd) You speak English? Are you a boy...

Or a girl...? The first Young Man leers and LAUGHS and then we suddenly his nose burst with blood as Einar’s fist connects. The t men are caught by surprise as he lashes out with terrific energy, but they regroup and then Einar’s down, fists and feet flying, the men beating him furiously, until they finally run away. INT. HANS AXGIL’S OFFICE, QUAI D’ORSAY, PARIS DAY Animated discussion between Hans and another man.

But I’m worried that will be too late. I can’t hold the buyers much longer... Hans’ secretary puts her head around the door. He glances up, annoyed, but something in her face gives him pause. Behind her, a man appears... A beat before Hans recognise the badly swollen face. HANS (cont'd) Einar... 26/11/15  63. INT. HANS AXGIL’S OFFICE, BATHROOM Hans tenderly cleans Einar’s face with iodine.
You're good at this.
I boxed for a while.
Shame you weren't with me earlier. Einar smiles at his own humour, but it hurts too much. EINAR (cont'd) Sorry I’ve never been to see you before.
That's alright. You’re here now.
I couldn't let Gerda see me this way. She has enough to put up with. Hans acknowledges the truth of this, carries on.
Let me know if you feel light-headed.
I’m permanently light-headed.
God, Einar, what’s happened to you? I don’t understand...
Ha - nor do I. But I don’t think it’s anything new... Even in Vejle...
What?
Well I was different.
It didn’t take much to be different in Vejle! Surely, that’s why we became friends? Einar nods, accepts Hans’ generosity. They take each othe in, the absurdity of their situation settling between the
I wanted to thank you for looking after Gerda. (CONTINUED)
Hans is slightly uneasy.
It’s no great hardship.
I’ve let her down.
She doesn’t think that. Einar struggles a moment, then:
Every morning I promise myself I’1l spend the whole day as Einar. But there’s so little Einar left.
You need building up...
No. I think Lili’s thoughts. All the time. Even here, now, I’m having to work so hard just to... to be me. To be this. He gestures, hopeless. But Hans won’t be defeated.
You think these things because you’re exhausted... Einar confesses.
I think sometimes about killing Einar. It’s only the thought that I’d be killing Lili too that stops me. Hans is appalled, struggles for words.
You need to see someone. A doctor.
No doctors. Hans lays his big hand heavily on his friend’s shoulder.

130 Yes, Einar. You have to try. 130 INT. DR BUSON’S CLINIC, ONE WEEK LATER, DAY Einar in a reclining chair, beside a pull-down chart of t human brain. He’s focused, engaged. BUSON seems excited. (CONTINUED)

A confused state of identity. He snaps down a diagram of the frontal lobe. BUSON (cont'd) I drill small holes - here, here and here... He touches Einar’s forehead... Einar blanches, surprised. INT. DR MCBRIDE’S ROOMS, ONE WEEK LATER A CLOCK TICKS in the self-conscious reconstruction of Fre consulting room. MCBRIDE adjusts his pince-nez.
I've listened carefully and I’m afraid it’s not good news. From the couch, Einar waits for the diagnosis. MCBRIDE (cont'd) You’re a homosexual. Einar fails to stifle a bitter laugh.

head_text.subj: INT. ETABLISSEMENT HYDROTHERAPIQUE, ONE WEEK LATER, DAY

text: Dr Mai observes Einar, fascinated, over tented fingers.
Well, I don’t really know what kind of help I need, but I can’t go on living without knowing who I am.
Mm... very good... Dr Mai nods vigorously, scribbles definitively onto a pad

Please excuse me a moment... He nods politely goes out, leaving Einar alone. Curiosity gets the better of Einar and he works his way to the desk looks at the pad. As the sun falls across it, he can clea see the imprint of a word: schizophrenic... Einar panics, grabs his coat...

Dr Mai hurries down the corridor flanked by male nurses. 26/11/15  66. INT. ETABLISSEMENT HYDROTHERAPIQUE, DR MAI’S ROOM, DAY Dr Mai and the men look on, impotent, as the lace curtain floats at the window onto the courtyard. Einar has gone.
Gerda comes home. The place is in darkness. She startles. Einar’s been waiting for her. Gerda sits.
Do you think I’m insane?
Did a doctor say that?
I’m sorry, I know we agreed no more... but look at me. She does - carefully, seeing Lili, just below the surface
You’re not insane. Einar’s grateful. Gerda fights emotion... GERDA (cont'd) Did I do this to you? Einar doesn’t understand...
What...?
Sometimes I think if it hadn’t been for the paintings...
Oh no... no, no. You helped bring Lili to life, but she was always... she was waiting...
But now she’s making you ill.
I don’t know what to do. The doctors can’t help me. Einar’s at the end of the road. Gerda broaches the subjec she most fears:
Do you want to try one more...? (CONTINUED)
Einar is surprised. What does Gerda have in mind?
Gerda and Einar sit, both nervous. Opposite, Warnekros observes Einar closely. A nervous tension in the air.
So what do you think would explain what you've been experiencing Mr Wegener?
Professor Warnekros... the fact is... I believe I am a woman inside.
And I believe it too. Einar looks to Gerda, grateful to hear her say this out l
You probably think I’m insane. That we both are... Warnekros smiles. He lights a cigarette, taking his time.

Well, there are people who think that I’m insane. But I think you’re probably right. Einar’s amazed. Warnekros breathes, begins: WARNEKROS (cont'd) I’ve met another man like you. Einar grasps Gerda’s hand, filled with hope... WARNEKROS (cont'd) I pursued his case - against the wishes of my colleagues, of course. Warnekros considers a moment, then: WARNEKROS (cont'd) I told him I could operate. To make him fully a woman.
Is that really possible? Einar and Gerda struggle to take in the idea.
What happened to the man? Was the operation successful? (CONTINUED)
It never took place. On the morning of the first operation, he ran away. He was too frightened.
I wouldn’t do that. Warnekros manages a grim laugh. Sounds a warning -—
Perhaps he was the smart one. The surgery has never been attempted before. Gerda tries to get a grip on things:
Professor Warnekros, what is this surgery...?

Two operations... The first to remove the male parts entirely. The second - once you were strong again - to construct a vagina. Gerda looks to Einar - Einar’s rapt. WARNEKROS (cont'd) An irreversible change, and a high risk of failure, of infection, complications. Warnekros’s hand waves through the air, suggesting the worst...
It’s too dangerous...
It’s my only hope. Gerda and Einar exchange a look. Warnekros observes.

I leave for Dresden at lunchtime tomorrow. He warns them, an unmistakably serious tone: WARNEKROS (cont'd) Mrs Wegener, I do believe I can help your husband. But he won’t be your husband when I’ve finished. 26/11/15

A NOISY bustling platform. People rushing in all directio Einar checks his ticket, about to board the train. Hans a Gerda are with him, almost swept away by the tide of peop Hans carries his case. They find a space in the crowd. Einar strains at his starched collar - his suit is emphatically masculine.
I feel strange going dressed like this.
It’s important. Hans says the Germans will check your papers.
Don’t take any chances. You’re nearly there. Hans and Einar embrace, then Hans holds him at arms lengt
I won’t be seeing you again.

You know, I’ve only really liked a handful of people in my life and you’ve been two of them. Einar half-laughs. Hans twinkles. HANS (cont'd) Take care. Take care. The men part. Hans withdraws. Einar turns to Gerda. What can he say? They hold one another close, intensely privat
I wish you’d let me come with you.
I can’t. You love Einar. And I have to let him go. They kiss, an emotional parting. She removes her bright scarf.

Here, take this... He takes it, smiles, and boards the train - just in time. The air fills with steam and NOISE. Gerda raises her hand wave as the train pulls out, carrying Einar away. Einar fights tears as he moves off... Gerda runs alongside a little way, the gap that’s opening between them suddenly unbearable. And then... the train has gone. Gerda turns t leave, finds Hans waiting. She walks past him, bereft. (CONTINUED)
Gerda...? Let me give you a lift. She barely turns, hands stuffed firmly in her pockets.
I’m going to walk. She strides down the platform, trying to outpace the pain face set, body strong. She could walk like this forever.
Einar watches the scenery fly by outside.
Gerda prepares a fresh canvas. INT. TINY BATHROOM ON TRAIN. Einar opens a document - his passport. Takes a long look
Next stop, Dresden. Dresden is the 148 next stop...

Gerda, charcoal in hand, the canvas before her, waits to begin. Then there’s a swift line on the canvas - the curv of a flank - conjures a nude Einar or Lili... Whatever na is attached to it now. She sketches the form of a body sh loves. Strong magic to keep it from harm.
Lili walks into town, a high road that gives her a panora view of the river. INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, RECEPTION, EARLY EVENING
Hello...?
Yes, my name is Lili, I’m here to see Professor Warnekros.
Lili what? (CONTINUED)
Lili wonders, surprised at the question...
Oh... Lili Elbe. Yes. Like the river. The Receptionist nods. Writes it down.

Please take a seat... Lili settles... looks around. A sanctuary. For women. INT. WARNEKROS’S OFFICE, EVENING Lili sits with Professor Warnekros. Behind him, anatomica models of women’s reproductive parts, plastic foetuses.
Must I really wait?

It’s only a week, We need you to rest and gain some weight. We can’t risk an infection. Professor Warnekros rises, rests his hands on Lili’s shoulders, paternal. Lili pats his hand, tender, submissi WARNEKROS (cont'd) For what I’m attempting, you’ll need to be strong.

This is not my body, Professor. Please take it away. EXT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, DRESDEN, GARDEN, DAY Lili amidst other young women patients, many pregnant. Sh concentrates on balancing a teacup on her knee. A VOICE:
Do you think Spring will come early? Lili looks round. A delicate blonde, URSULA, sits nearby. URSULA (cont'd) I saw you looking at the crocuses.
Oh - yes. You’re having a baby. Ursula nods, cradles her round belly.
And you? (CONTINUED)
No - I’m ill inside. But Professor Warnekros’s going to make me better. He’s operating tomorrow.
Will you be able to have children after? The question catches Lili by surprise, sets her thinking.
I don’t know.
I hope so. Lili smiles, full of optimism. INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, DRESDEN, LILI’S ROOM, EVENING A particularly solicitous NURSE gives Lili a white pill.
To help you sleep tonight. Later - Lili at the sink, wipes a washcloth over her face The water runs a peachy colour as powder and rouge rinse away. Lili looks in the mirror at Einar for the last time
Hans smokes his cigar. Picks a speck of tobacco from his tongue.
Rasmussen called. The Dufour people want you in their group show. I like the idea. Gerda looks across at him, hasn’t heard anything.
I'm sorry?
The Dufour Gallery? But Gerda shakes her head. Hans SIGHS, considers, then: HANS (cont'd) Gerda, why don’t you go...?
He asked me not to. (CONTINUED)
He wanted to protect you. You should be there. I'll go with you. Gerda turns on him:
No. If I go, it’ll be alone.
Now you’re sounding like Einar.
I am like Einar. Hans seethes, frustrated.
What do you want me to do Gerda?
I want you to go away. Hans is surprised, hurt.
Really? Gerda looks down, fixes her eyes on a burn mark on the tabletop. She senses movement as Hans chair is pushed asi

No, I’m sorry... But it’s too late. Hans is gone. INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, DRESDEN, NEXT DAY Einar/Lili sleeps a deep sleep. We pull out to see the operating theatre around her, Warnekros prepped to begin. INT. PROFESSOR WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, DRESDEN, CORRIDOR/LILI’S ROOM Warnekros escorts Gerda along the corridor.

She only regained consciousness very briefly. We’re having to give her a great deal of morphine, of course, so that’s to be expected. As they reach Lili’s room, a CRY fills Gerda with fear. (CONTINUED)

WARNEKROS (cont'd) It’s nothing, I assure you... Gerda is stunned to see Lili held down by ropes weighted sandbags. She looks terrible, grey-green, exhausted. A nurse administers morphine, another soothes.
You mustn’t move Lili. It only makes it worse...
(under her breath) My God... The nurse pushes a paralysed Gerda gently aside -—
Excuse me... The nurse slips a mask over Lili’s face. She sucks gratefully at the numbing gas. Gerda comes to, galvanises herself, moves the nurse aside, takes hold of the mask.

I’ll do that. I’m here now. Don’t worry, I’m here... The nurse looks to Warnekros - he nods. She withdraws. Ge smooths Lili’s brow, determined, devoted. EXT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, GARDEN, TWO WEEKS LATER, DAY Lili dozes in her wheelchair. Gerda sketches. Lili smiles little but her eyes don’t open. Gerda notices, stops.
I can feel I’m getting better when I listen to your pencil. She opens her eyes. LILI (cont'd) You’ve always sketched me better than I was.
Have I...?

What you draw, I become. You made me more beautiful, now you’re making me strong. Such power in you. Gerda smiles. Lili reaches out and touches her hands. Lili’s eyes shine, full of anticipation. (CONTINUED)
LILI (cont'd) Shall we go back to Denmark then, Gerda? Shall we go home?

head_text.subj: INT. WIDOW HOUSE, COPENHAGEN. STUDIO, 1 MONTH LATER, DAY

text: Gerda CRACKS the lock on the shutters, pushes them open, flooding the long-dark room with light. Outside, the bust harbour -
Lili! Lili, you’re late... 166 Lili appears. She’s excited - dressed, made up... Gerda holds out a little pill-box. GERDA (CONT'D) (cont’d) So, these...
Every two hours. And I have to eat something first. I have a few macaroons in my bag all ready.
And these, only if you need them. Lili salutes like a girl guide. Gerda marvels at her... s alive. GERDA (cont'd) Good luck. Lili leaves. Gerda breathes again. A new beginning.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET OUTSIDE THE WIDOW HOUSE, DAY

text: Lili makes her way down the street, her confidence slowly building. A man lifts his hat as she passes and she looks away, surprised and pleased. INT. FONNESBECH’S DEPARTMENT STORE, DAY Lili hangs on the glamourous Manageress’s instructions. F perfectly with the other painted dolls behind the perfume counter.
And remember, making a purchase at Fonnesbech’s is not merely shopping. It’s an experience! You lived in Paris, yes?
Oh yes... (CONTINUED)

Let everyone know! The store is a stage - we are here to perform. Lili looks out over the cut-glass bottles and endlessly reflecting surfaces, thrilled ... INT. FONNESBECH’S DEPARTMENT STORE, DAY Lili at work. She explains to an older female customer:

And in Paris, a lady would never dream of spraying the scent directly onto herself. The woman listens, entranced by Lili’s animated lecture. LILI (CONT'D) (cont'd) No, you spray the air, see, and walk into it... Lili skips into the mist of scent. LILI (CONT'D) (cont'd) Voila..! Lili skips into the mist of scent. LILI (cont'd) You try... The woman is shy, but Lili’s enthusiasm is so infectious. Later: Lili rearranges the perfume bottles on the counter until they are perfectly aligned... a real satisfaction i the aesthetic endeavour. INT. FONNSBECH’S DEPARTMENT STORE Lili and her colleagues pour out of the store, demob-happ Lili offers them sweets from her handbag.
It’s so unfair - you’ve got the sweetest tooth and the narrowest hips in the whole store...
How do you manage it, eating so much sugar?
Oh, the trick is to eat nothing else... (CONTINUED)
They all LAUGH. Lili moves to go...
See you tomorrow! The Girl hurries into the arms of her waiting boyfriend. Lili watches, intrigued. Until -
Lili - are you coming... And Lili rejoins the throng.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET RUNNING PAST CANAL, DAY

text: Lili walks along the canals, savouring the journey. The s sparkles on the water, and all around people are meeting talking, a world of life that she finally feels part of.. INT. WIDOW HOUSE, GERDA’S SIDE OF THE ROOM, NIGHT A quiet, dreamy atmosphere. Gerda lies awake, watches Lil lamplit silhouette on the other side of the dividing shee Lili writes in her notebook. After a while:
You know one night last week, I had the strangest dream.
What...?
I dreamed you were getting married. Lili’s silhouette sits up...
Do you think I ever will...?
Who knows? So many strange things have happened. GERDA (cont'd) It’s not so long ago we were married... you and me. Gerda waits in the silence for some response.
You and Einar.
I know it was Einar. But really it was you and me. (CONTINUED)
They both absorb this idea... Lili’s silhouette waits a moment, then lies back down. Ge curls into herself.

Lili passes the cafe on the Harbour as usual, glances ove Her footsteps slow... Sitting alone at a table is a famil face: Henrik looks up from his newspaper: Lili. He looks shocked... then delighted...
Is it really you...? Lili smiles...
I believe so. They begin to laugh, lit up with euphoria. Henrik hurries pull out a chair for Lili to sit down...
Lili and Henrik at a table together. Henrik is stunned.
So what you’re suggesting is.. Lili tilts her head, waiting, pleased with herself... HENRIK (cont'd) That a doctor... Henrik glances around, lowers his voice... HENRIK (cont'd) ...intervened...
To correct a mistake in nature. I have a passport to prove it.
He made you a woman...? Lili bridles slightly, corrects him kindly -
God made me a woman. The doctor cured the sickness that was my disguise. Henrik pushes, still struggling. Lili’s confidence ebbs.. (CONTINUED)
A real woman? The question hangs between them.
Lili sits writing in her notebook, all seriousness. Gerda looks up from reading. Lili takes a pill, resumes writing
You're going to need a new notebook if you carry on like this.
When Professor Warnekros suggested I keep a diary... well, I thought I'd never have anything to write. But it helps, to make sense of things.
Perhaps I should try it. Lili almost smiles. GERDA (cont'd) Do you never think of painting? Lili’s surprised. GERDA (cont'd) You might be good at it.
I want to be a woman, not a painter.

Well, people have been known to do both. I'd be curious to see what you painted, that’s all. Sometimes it’s hard to know what’s in your... Lili takes a pill, testy. Gerda’s can’t help herself: GERDA (CONT'D) (cont’d) Didn't you just take one of those a minute ago?
Gerda, I know what I’m doing. Gerda backs off. LILI (CONT'D) (cont'd) I’m going to get some fresh air. (CONTINUED)

Lili gets her coat and Gerda’s wool wrap. But as Lili hea for the door - LILI (cont'd) You know sometimes I wonder why you let me go through all this if you thought everything would be the same afterwards. Gerda’s wrongfooted...
I didn’t. But I promised Einar I'd take care of you.

For goodness’ sake, Gerda - Einar is dead. We both have to accept that. You took care of me, now I have to take care of myself. I have to have a life of my own. And you need to do the same. Lili calls the dog, heads for the door, and is gone. Gerd is left alone to process this exchange...
In the studio, Gerda reorganises, determined - paints, brushes, solvents everywhere. She has already taken down most of the sketches from her studio wall. It is blank - clean sheet. She considers...

head_text.subj: EXT. PHONE KIOSK ON HARBOUR, DAY

text: Gerda paces, exercised, all nervous indecision. Resolves enter the booth... We hear a PHONE RINGING. INT. HANS AXGIL’S OFFICE, PARIS, RECEPTION, DAY The Receptionist at her desk, on the phone:
Yes, in London... Is it urgent? Should I could ask him to..?

head_text.subj: EXT. PHONE KIOSK ON HARBOUR, DAY

text: Gerda, on the phone, disappointed, wrong-footed.
Oh, no that’s fine. Just tell him... just say... (CONTINUED)
She struggles to compose a message. GERDA (CONT'D) (cont’d) It’s a beautiful day in Copenhagen. She hangs up, discomposed. Feeling like a stupid teenager
Gerda passes the fish stall, greets the female fishmonger then sees Lili, up ahead, on Henrik’s arm. Henrik sees Gerda... alerts Lili. Gerda nods politely and quickly hea in the opposite direction.
Food cooking on the stove. Gerda drinks a glass of wine, thoughtful. Lili arrives home, on eggshells...
It’s not what you think. Henrik is homosexual. There’s nothing between us. But I should have told you I'd seen him.
No you shouldn’t...
He’s just a friend, Gerda. Someone to talk to.
(without rancour) Because you can’t talk to me. Gerda pours wine for Lili. She accepts the glass.

About some things, no. Gerda lifts her glass, proposing a muted toast, but Lili something more on her mind... LILI (cont'd) I’ve made a decision. I’m going back to Dresden. For the second operation. Gerda’s blood runs cold.
It’s too soon. (CONTINUED)
No, it’s time. I need to finish what I started.
You’re not strong enough...
Professor Warnekros thinks I am...
Warnekros...? He hasn’t seen you.
I’ve made up my mind. Gerda shakes her head, disbelief...
It could kill you.
I’m going on Friday. Will you come with me? Gerda’s mind races to absorb the announcement...
I won’t help you to hurt yourself. Lili bites down on it:
Gerda, will you come...? INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, LILI’S ROOM, RAINY NIGHT 82. Lili’s sitting up in bed, Gerda’s bright scarf around her shoulders. Warnekros holds Lili’s wrist, checks the pulse
This will be harder than the last operation? You understand that.
Yes I do. A note of warning.
It’s complex surgery.
And I‘1l sleep all the way through it! (CONTINUED)
Yes you will, but...

You’1l be there when I wake up. Lili half-jokes: LILI (cont'd) I want a husband who looks just like you! Then, more thoughtful: LILI (CONT'D) (cont'd) And maybe a child. Like a real woman. Warnekros nods, kindly, but...

One step at a time. He gets up. WARNEKROS (cont'd) Get some rest, now. Goodnight. He smiles, goes to the door. Gerda’s waiting outside. The cross in the doorway, polite but not warm. Lili smiles, seeing Gerda. Gerda sits on the bed.
You're still angry with me.
I’m not angry with you, I’m worried about you. Gerda lays her head in Lili’s lap, tired with anxiety. Li strokes her hair. We feel the depth of love between them.
You heard my wish Gerda. When no one else could hear me, you did. Gerda’s eyes begin to fill. She collects herself.
Come. We both need our rest. I can sleep in the chair, there...
Off to your little hotel.
I don’t mind... (CONTINUED)
But Lili insists.
Are there chocolates on the pillow?
Cigarette burns. Lili laughs, kisses Gerda’s cheek.
Take this... There’s a chill in the air. Lili goes to hand over Gerda’s scarf, but:
You keep it. For now. Lili smiles, a little mischievous. But then a look betwee them. Gerda’s afraid.
I’m going to be fine. Gerda nods, determined to believe it.
Yes.
Sleep well.

Goodnight. Lili is determinedly bright. Gerda takes her coat and bag The door closes behind her. A couple of moments pass and then Lili begins to dissolve, releasing tears of overwhel fear and anticipation...
The CONCIERGE approaches, solicitous.

Room 9. The concierge turns to get Gerda’s key. The sound of a cocktail piano in an adjacent room serves to reinforce he isolation. But then she sees reflected in the mirror - a familiar face - GERDA (CONT'D) (cont'd) Hans...? (CONTINUED)
Gerda turns, barely holding herself together... he catche her in a heavy, passionate embrace. A huge sense of relie reunion, trust.
It’s alright. Gerda nods, greatly comforted by his presence.
Yes.
Everything will be alright. Gerda hangs on to Hans, desperately wanting it to be true INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, LILI’S ROOM, DAWN A nurse helps a quietly determined Lili into a surgical g
Warnerkros, scrubbed in, serious, ready to begin.

Good luck, everybody. Lili anaesthetised. We stay on her face, hear voices, the clank of instruments. Rain beginning... the sound of it increasingly intense as the wind comes up too... INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, RECEPTION, NEXT MORNING Morning light streams in, harsh, unforgiving. Hans holds door for Gerda. She’s barely inside when the Receptionist jumps urgently to her feet.

Professor Warnekros would like a word... Gerda’s faces register anxiety. Hans gestures - he’s back off. He’ll wait. Gerda hurries away. INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, DRESDEN, MORNING Warnekros and Gerda walk purposefully along the corridor
She lost a lot of blood. Now we’re struggling to keep the fever down. There’s a chance it will burn itself out, but... (CONTINUED)

They arrive at the doorway to Lili’s room. Warnekros show Gerda in. Lili sleeps fitfully, slick with sweat. * Warnekros’s clearly worried. Gerda’s astonished at how il she looks. WARNEKROS (CONT'D) (cont'd) (deeply regretful) I’m sorry... I have to be honest. The prognosis is not... He can’t finish, but Gerda barely hears him anyway...

Go away... thank you. Leave us * alone. Gerda hangs in the doorway, blocking it, until Warnekros obliged to turn away. We follow him, walking back down th corridor, alone, excluded, burdened by failure. * INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, DRESDEN, GARDEN, NIGHT Heavy spots of rain begin to splash down. Most of the hospital in darkness. A light glowing in one room. INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, DRESDEN, LILI’S ROOM, NIGHT Gerda in the chair at Lili’s bedside, mopping her brow. T rainstorm beating outside. A nurse enters with a jug of water. Gerda nods, grateful. INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, DRESDEN, CORRIDOR, DAWN A cleaner works her mop and bucket down the corridor. Han sleeps in a chair up ahead. INT. WARNEKROS’S CLINIC, DRESDEN, LILI’S ROOM Lili sleeping, calmer now. Her face translucent in the morning light. Gerda sleeps in the chair beside her. Gerd wakes, disoriented for a moment, then looks at Lili, slee peacefully, clearly cooler now... Gerda feels her brow - heat there any more... Gerda’s relief is palpable. She smooths Lili’s fringe, then gets up, opens the curtains - wide - the sun just starting to show in the rain-washed s She turns back to see Lili’s eyes open.
Lili...? Lili struggles to speak. (CONTINUED)
GERDA (cont'd) I’m here... just lie still... It’s alright... Lili smiles through her medicated haze. She sees Hans hur in... thrilled to see her awake...
Oh, Lili. How are you? Her voice is faint, cracked. She takes in Hans and Gerda:
I am... entirely myself. Hans laughs gently.
I‘1l tell Warnekros she’s awake. Hans goes. Gerda sits back beside Lili, fixes her hair.
You know you had us worried... Lili’s frail, otherworldly, but her eyes burn bright. She looks to the window.
Can I go outside, Gerda? Into the garden?
I think you should rest... But Lili takes Gerda’s hand, a great sense of calm in her She looks at Gerda. Gerda still there, always there.
Please...

Gerda wheels Lili out in a wheelchair, Hans holding the d open for her to pass. A glance between him and Gerda, the he leaves the women alone. Gerda is settles herself in a chair beside Lili, rests he hand on Lili’s arm. The birch trees in Spring leaf. A lig breeze makes them quiver. Lili’s breathing is shallow. We feel the depth of love between the women, and the precariousness of their situation.
You mustn’t worry about me any more, Gerda. (CONTINUED)
It’s an old habit. I’m slow to change.
How have I ever deserved such love? Gerda struggles to remain composed. LILI (cont'd) I’m sorry you were frightened. There’s nothing to be afraid of any more.
No.
You know, last night, I had the most beautiful dream... I dreamed I was a baby in my mother’s arms... and she looked down at me... and called me Lili... Gerda is amazed, deeply moved...

Lili... Lili’s features arrange themselves into an expression of perfect joy as she sinks back into something which Gerda gradually sees is deeper than sleep... GERDA (cont'd) Lili... Gerda clutches the hand... No response... Smooths the brow... still nothing... GERDA (CONT'D) (cont'd) Lili...? Gerda presses Lili’s hand against her cheek, overwhelmed grief. Lili looks blissfully happy. The dawn light grows stronger in the garden...

head_text.subj: INT/EXT. JUTLAND, DAWN, TWO WEEKS LATER

text: Hans’ car rolls into the bleak landscape. Hans and Gerda inside. Gerda looks out - at a landscape she knows with absolute intimacy, although she’s never been here before. It’s all here... the imagery from Einar’s paintings, sing with life... A wild stretch of rocky green under soft northern light, a row of beautiful black-limbed trees, be over, but not broken, by the wind... 26/11/15  89.

head_text.subj: EXT. CLIFFS OVERLOOKING KATTEGAT SEA, JUTLAND, MORNING

text: Hans tails Gerda. She battles the incredible gusts of sal air, the bright scarf flying like a flag at her throat. S pushes on, closer to the cliff edge... Finally she reache an amazing vantage point, is stunned by the view: a recta of ferociously stormy sea, silver waves whipped by a wind that stings, relentless. We hear the RUSTLE and PUNCH of weather going at her. Hans joins her. They stand there looking out until they can hardly breathe any more. Hans takes her armto steady her, but as she turns toward the wind rips up under the bright scarf, snatches it into air. Gerda GASPS - a moment of loss - but then, something else... As Hans hurries to try and catch it -

No - leave it..! Leave it.. She pulls him back, watches it dance, tears of joy in her eyes... GERDA (CONT’D) Let it fly... The scarf swoops up and dives down, curls and rolls, as f as child... a girl at play. Gerda clutches her coat at he breast, almost delirious at the beauty of it. Hans watche with her - the absurdly joyous spectacle of it, a stunnin farewell. And as the scarf dances out from the cliff, out sea... into eternity...
